p: While drugs are administered to cure infections or mitigate symptoms, they may also affect the magnitude or duration of infectiousness. Clinical trials of remdesivir and other promising antiviral drugs are underway ( https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?cond=COVID-19), but none has yet been proven effective against SARS-CoV-2. This is the mechanism underlying the “treatment as prevention” approach to reducing HIV infection rates. Treatment of infected people with anti-retroviral drugs reduces their viral load, preventing their progression to AIDS. Authorities believe that it also reduces their infectiousness, which would lower the effective reproduction number. This is the rationale for the US national initiative, “Ending the HIV Epidemic: A Plan for America” ( https://www.hiv.gov/federal-response/ending-the-hiv-epidemic/overview).
